content: What should I learn here? DP? Sequences? Or is it a spoiler?

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I accept this contribution because.

I'm stumped.

I find the same results as you for K=1, K=2, and the entire simple and intermediate sets of K=3, and precious few of the advanced and mixed.

Namely, I find different results for the entire K=3 advanced test case, for tests 1 3 5 7 and 8 (1-indexed) of the advanced validation case, and test 1 of the mixed validation case.

The failed validator that passes tests is bad, I suppose it ought to be swapped.

But I'd like to understand the difference more deeply. Would you care to detail your dp parameters, so I can compare with mine? (I'm using what I assume is the same as damiengif's method, but with an O(slightly smaller) matrix, and longhand (because I'm lazy, remember)).

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice problem.

Given that 'K' comes before 'N' in input, could you make sure that 'K' appears before 'N' in the spec as well? In particular, 'K x N' in the 1st line and 'K = xxx and N = yyy' in your examples.
(I know it does not matter much, but it won't hurt either)

By the way, I solved this using 3D DP as well, so I was wondering how one could solve it using a "much better way" (as you mentioned in an earlier comment).

Otherwise, nice problem. Well suited for the medium category imho.
As for a story, this kind of stuff is usually illustrated with tilling a bathroom or splitting a chocolate bar... But given the constraints of your puzzle, not so sure how one could adapt the stories to fit the puzzle.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Interesting problem, that has not been treated in other CG puzzles to my knowledge.
Also, can someone suggest a story for this problem?
The puzzle would be hard for me since I solved with a 3 variable dp, but I've heard there's much better ways to do it, so it's upto the community.

Hello, in the game specifications, you missed to put the 'K' input, there is only 'N'. 
The line 
"Next T Lines: An integer N, the width of the grid" 
should be
"Next T Lines: An integer K the height of the grid, and N, the width of the grid".
and the in the constraints, add the line:
"1 <= K <= 3"
Thanks. Done.

That's kind of a problem, though.
I'm not quite sure a dynamic language could solve even K=2 with simple DP within the current time constraints.

I think if I squint I see the better version, but... implementing straight DP is so much lazier.

I'd rather have confirmation the smart way works before approving.

Thanks for the approval. I made the changes you asked for. I should probably also change the test case names, I'll try to do that too.

EDIT: Updated the Test Case names. Hope it's all good now :D

Did you forgot a factor 2(symetry) in some transition or missed any transition (n-3)->n (ie 3 horizontal lines)?

You should get f(3,9)=35.

I hope it helps.
Mostly Sequences, yeah should have added that tag. Actually depends on your approach I guess.

The 3 variable dp I used has the following meanings:

dp1 is the ways of tiling a 3*k block
dp2 is the ways of tiling a 3*k block with one corner removed
dp3 is the ways of tiling a 3*k block with a 2*1 block removed from one corner.

As to swapping of test case and validator, which test case is it?

With states s_i, i being the number of  remaining squares in a column, I have 2 ways to go from s_0(n-2) to s_1(n) : 
2*2 piece and 1*3 
or 
1*3 piece and2*2
My code would distinguish whether the 1*3 is top or bottom. So I do have the two ways, they're just not summed directly.

Hmm..
Int overflow?
Got it. Will change it.
Actually I think I will wait for the "why" to come out, then we can can add a similar case to the testcase. So as to prevent a lucky submission.
Int overflow... let me get back to you on that.

Int overflow it is. Good call, thanks!

That'll teach me to be *so* lazy.

So for a quick summary: I only `mod`ded on vertical splits. And for N around 400k, that's not enough anymore.

So I'd suggest making the K=3 cases in the "mixed" validator easier than the test as a matter of principle, and if you're in a very generous mood, add a nice semi-advanced case that covers the problem range extensively.
I'll make the changes tomorrow.

I've added a test case. (it's the same for test and validation—I know, but I can't make up word sizes just to make it different!)
It tests the last N before and first N after integer overflow on 31, 32, 53.0001, 63 and 64 bits.

It's good for approval for me, if that's fine by you.
All good. Thanks for doing it :D

I solved it with an (3^K * 3^K) Adjacency matrix exponentiation, which is O(27^K*log N).
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adjacency_matrix
:O Thanks
